questions.text: Which of the following is false about mental health?

choices.text: Mental disorders are universal, not specific to any group
Mental health is the mere absence of mental illness
Heredity can contribute to mental illnesses
Substance abuse is a type of mental illness

questions.solution:
Mental health is a state of well-being in which an individual realizes his or her own abilities and not merely the absence of mental illness. It is the ability to cope with stress, be productive, and contribute to the community. 

Mental disorders are universal and are not specific to any particular group. They are associated with hereditary (family history of psychiatric disorders) and environmental factors. Substance abuse and alcohol addiction are considered types of mental illness.

questions.text:
Which of the following are sociopathological factors associated with mental health?
  1. Economic insecurity
  2. Anxiety
  3. Substance abuse
  4. Frustration
  5. Radiation
questions.solution:
Economic insecurity, anxiety, and frustration are the sociopathological factors associated with mental health.

The factors leading to mental health illnesses include:

  • Organic - cerebral arteriosclerosis, neoplasms, endocrine, metabolic and chronic diseases
  • Hereditary - schizophrenia
  • Socio-pathological factors - worries, anxiety, frustration, emotional stress, tension, unhappy marriages, broken homes, poverty, industrialization, urbanization, changing family structure, population mobility, economic insecurity, cruelty, rejection, neglect.
  • Environmental - environmental toxins, substance abuse, radiation, nutritional factors, mineral deficiencies, infectious diseases during prenatal, perinatal, and postnatal periods (like rubella), road traffic accidents.

questions.text: The incidence of mental illness is higher in individuals who are exposed to causal factors during which period of life?
questions.solution:
Exposure to causal factors during the initial 5 years of life leads to an increased incidence of mental illness.

This period is critical for lifelong mental health behavior and learning, even more crucial than adolescence. During early childhood, the growth and development of children are most vulnerable to external environmental stressors.  A continuous, intimate, and warm relationship with the child's parents during infancy and childhood is very important.

questions.text: All of the following can be used for the secondary prevention of mental illness in patients except:
questions.solution:
Improving the social environment is a method of primary prevention of mental illness, not secondary prevention. 

The levels of prevention of mental illness and measures are given below:

  • Primary prevention - improving the social environment and the promotion of mental health awareness
  • Secondary prevention - early diagnosis and family-based health services like casework and family counseling
  • Tertiary prevention - measures to reduce the duration of mental illness as well family and community stresses to prevent further breakdown and disruption

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are considered to have a major mental illness?
questions.solution:
Patients with manic depressive psychosis are considered to have a major mental illness. 

Mental health disorders are classified as:

  • Major (psychotic or not in touch with reality) - include schizophrenia, manic depressive psychosis, and paranoia
  • Minor (non-psychotic, remain in touch with reality) - include neuroses (like OCD), personality and character disorders

Dementia occurs secondary to organic causes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a service offered to patients with mental health disorders?
questions.solution:
Employment services are not included under mental health services.

Mental health services include:

  • Early diagnosis and treatment
  • Group and individual psychotherapy
  • Mental health education
  • Use of modern psychoactive drugs
  • Rehabilitation
  • After-care services - help drug-dependent persons to adapt to regular life following treatment and rehabilitation

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the casualty with a suspected drug overdose. His sister tells you that he has recently started taking a 'superman drug' after hearing about it from his friends. What drug is she referring to?
questions.solution:
Amphetamines are also known as the superman drug. 

This is because their effects include increased self-confidence and endurance. However, its usage leads to tolerance and dependence.

questions.text: What is currently the most widely used illicit substance in the world?
questions.solution:
Cannabis is the most widely used illicit substance in the world.

Cannabis is obtained from Cannabis sativa, C. indica, and C. americana. It is colloquially called marijuana. Other forms of this drug are charas or hashish and bhang.

questions.text: What is the most widely used legal addictive substance in India?
questions.solution: Tobacco is the most widely used legal addictive substance in India, followed closely by alcohol as the second most widely consumed substance.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an objective of the National Mental Health Programme of 1982?

choices.text: Ensure equal human rights to mentally ill
Promote community participation in mental health services
Promote application of mental health knowledge
Provide accessibility of mental health care

questions.solution:
Ensuring equal rights to mentally ill people is not an objective of the National Mental Health Programme (NMHP). It was launched in 1982 with the following objectives:

  • Ensure availability and accessibility of minimum mental health care
  • Encourage the application of mental health knowledge in general care
  • Promote community participation in mental health services development

The National Mental Health Programme was relaunched as The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 which includes provisions for equal rights for those with mental illness.

World Mental Health Day, observed on October 10th, highlights the importance of mental well-being. This year's theme, "It is Time to Prioritize Mental Health in the Workplace," stresses the need for businesses to foster supportive environments. Safe, healthy workplaces protect mental health, while stigma and poor conditions pose serious risks. By involving those with lived experiences and investing in evidence-based solutions, we can create workplaces where everyone thrives.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the District Mental Health Programme?
questions.solution:
Screening is not a component of the District Mental Health Programme. It includes the following components:

  • Training of all mental health workers at the nodal institute in the state
  • Increasing public awareness by education to reduce stigma
  • Early detection and treatment
  • Providing data for future planning, improvement in service and research

Activities by the DMHP for positive mental health include:

  • School mental health services
  • College counseling services
  • Workplace stress management
  • Suicide prevention services

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017?

choices.text: Advance directive rights of the mentally ill
Procedure for admission, treatment and discharge of the mentally ill

questions.solution:
Establishing mobile mental health camps for the benefit of mentally ill patients is not included under the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017.

This act encourages the mobilization of resources to improve mental health care across the country as well as reduce stigma and improve social inclusion/support for those with mental illness. It also has provisions to improve outcomes and protect their rights.

The provisions of this act include:

  • Rights of persons with mental illness to access health care, live without discrimination and enjoy confidentiality.
  • Advance directives to allow mentally ill people to make decisions about their treatment 
  • Procedures for admission, treatment (behavioral and interpersonal therapy, medications), and discharge 
  • Decriminalizing suicide and prohibiting electroconvulsive therapy unless anesthesia is used

The act also has clear instructions for the central and state mental health authorities and other mental health establishments on their endeavors.

questions.text: According to the WHO Mental Health Gap Action Programme, which of the following is not included in the Mental Health Care Act, 2017?
questions.solution:
According to the WHO Mental Health Gap Action Programme (mhGAP), screening of family members is not included in the Mental Health Care Act, 2017.

The Mental Healthcare Act of 2017 has provisions that include:

  • Rights of persons with mental illness to access health care, live without discrimination and enjoy confidentiality.
  • Advance directives to allow mentally ill people to make decisions about their treatment 
  • Procedures for admission, treatment (behavioral and interpersonal therapy, medications), and discharge 
  • Decriminalizing suicide and prohibiting electroconvulsive therapy unless anesthesia is used

These are achieved through the mobilization of resources to required areas, and by providing social support.

On October 10th, 2023, World Mental Health Day gives an opportunity for people and communities to come together under the banner of the subject "Mental health is a universal human right" The purpose is to expand awareness, raise consciousness, and motivate initiatives to develop and protect everyone's mental health, seeing it as a basic human right.

questions.text: The National Suicide Prevention Strategy aims to reduce suicide mortality by _______ in the country by 2030.
questions.solution:
The National Suicide Prevention Strategy (NSPS) aims to reduce suicide mortality by 10% in India by 2030. It is a multisectoral approach that will involve national and international government ministries, families, communities, and educational institutes to help prevent suicide.

India has a high burden of suicide. It is the leading cause of death among individuals between 15-29 years of age.

Epidemiology

  • Young and middle-aged adults between 18-45 years
  • Males more than females
  • Daily wage earners and people who earn <1,00,000 per annum
  • Individuals with family issues and illnesses

Hanging and poisoning were the most common methods of suicide. It accounts for >3/4th of all suicides.

Risk factors for suicide

  • Psychiatric illnesses- Depression, BPD, schizophrenia, and anxiety disorders
  • Alcohol and other substance abuse disorders
  • Major physical illness
  • Job or financial loss
  • Relationship or social loss
  • Domestic violence or abuse
  • Lack of social support 
  • The stigma associated with help-seeking behavior of mental disorders
  • Lack of social support and sense of isolation.

In the past 3 years, the suicide rate in India has increased from 10.2 to 11.3 per lakh population.i.e. 1 in 3 Women & 1 in 4 Men dying from suicide worlwide, is from India. In order to address this MOHFW has recently rolled out the first National Suicide Prevention Strategy, formulated in accordance with WHO's South East Asian regional strategy on suicide prevention. 

World suicide prevention day is on the 10th of September. "Creating Hope Through Action" is the triennial theme for World Suicide Prevention Day from 2021 to 2023. This topic is a compelling call to action and a reminder that there is an alternative to suicide and that we can foster hope and increase prevention through our actions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the REDS path in the National suicide prevention strategy?

choices.text: Reduce suicidal deaths by 2% in the next 5 years
Enhance health services to provide suicide prevention strategies
Develop community resilience, and societal support for suicide prevention

questions.solution:
The National Suicide Prevention Strategy (NSPS) is a multisectoral approach that will involve national and international government ministries, families and communities, and educational institutes. It aims to reduce suicide mortality by 10% in India by 2030.

It recommends REDS path for suicide prevention.

  • Reinforce leadership, partnership, and institutional capacity in the country
  • Enhance the health services capacity to provide suicide prevention services
  • Develop community resilience, societal support for suicide prevention and reduce stigma against suicidal behaviours
  • Strengthen surveillance and evidence generation. 

Objectives

  • To establish effective surveillance mechanism for suicide prevention in next 3 years
  • To establish psychiatric OPDs that provide suicide prevention services through District Mental Health Programme, within next 5 years
  • To integrate mental well-being curriculum in all educational institutes within next 8 years.
